results.title: My new home
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Jaya Sharma
results.brief_description: A story of a young woman’s life journey - from a young bride in India to become the head of Hindi radio at SBS in Melbourne. Created in the ACMI ‘Diversity@Work’ Digital Storytelling program in association with Diversity @ Work, AMES, Australia POst and SBS.

results.title: River of my Life
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Amira Sabanovic
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Amira describes the course her life has taken - from the ravages of War in her homeland through to the hardships of a refugee’s life in both Europe and Australia before finding acceptance and fulfillment through a supportive workplace.
results.description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Amira describes the course her life has taken - from the ravages of War in her homeland through to the hardships of a refugee’s life in both Europe and Australia before finding acceptance and fulfillment through a supportive workplace.

results.title: The Cute machine
results.brief_description:
‘The Cute machine’ is an exploration into the morphology of cute characterisation and iconography and its relationship to the biological world, seeking to analyse this ‘Cute ideal’ by correlating it with the Zoological process known as Neoteny

The CD contains two sections that had already been exhibited as installations (Sorry! and Activity Station) but were then adapted to a screen version. The remaining sections elaborate on the themes of cute iconography and its analysis.

The Cute Machine proposes an environment where cute iconography and user friendliness have rampantly accelerated, and reduced computer interface design to the look and sophistication of an infant toy, while also taking the premise, Cute = young to the extreme, where the ‘Cutest’, becomes an abstracted mutation of the original sentiment.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Papua New Guinea and United States, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a trip to the USA and Australia. It includes footage of the World Trade Centre twin towers and the Statue of Liberty in NYC, Disneyland, Pearl Harbour in Hawaii, Puffing Billy in Melbourne, views of Sydney Harbour, and a snippet back in New Guinea.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:15:00 group of friends of filmmaker gather at a pier
00:02:00:00 view of Twin Towers and the Statue of Liberty from a ferry
00:05:00:00 Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado
00:11:28:00 a visit to Disneyland and a zoo
00:15:53:00 a visit to Pearl Harbour, USS Arizona Memorial in Honolulu, Hawaii, with views from a ferry and of local resort
00:18:45:00 friends with a baby in the Dandenong Ranges, featuring Puffing Billy in Emerald
00:19:54:00 views of Sydney Harbour, Opera House, Harbour Bridge from a high level of a hotel
00:20:14:00 long lost children’s playground featuring UFO style fizzy dizzy’s and sides and seesaws
00:20:22:00 back to New Guinea, a celebration or demonstration
